thread.title: Iranian Montrealer facing deportation held at Laval detention centre
thread.title_full: Iranian Montrealer facing deportation held at Laval detention centre

author: cbc
title: Iranian Montrealer facing deportation held at Laval detention centre

organizations.name: montreal institute for genocide and human rights studies

text:
Roghayeh Azizi Mirmahleh, 60, told Canada Border Services Agency that returning to Iran would be a death sentence.
Mirmahleh spent three years in an Iranian prison for political activism before moving to Canada five years ago.
She says she and her husband distributed pamphlets in Iran printed by the Mujahedin-e Khalq (MEK), an exiled opposition group that backs the overthrow of the Islamic Republic of Iran.
"Iranian regime actually executed her husband. Her love. In Iran, she doesn't have any basic right to even visit his grave," said her daughter, Sahar Bahrami, translating for her mother.
Iranian interrogators 'threatened to send my dead body back to Canada': Homa Hoodfar Quebec man facing deportation 20 years after crime gets 2-year stay Held in Laval detention centre Sahar Bahrami, Roghayeh Azizi Meermahleh's daughter, is worried her mother's health will deteriorate in the Laval detention centre where she's now being held. (CBC)
Azizi Mirmahleh is set to be deported on Feb. 28, after a Canadian immigration officer decided last month that it's safe to send her back.
But at a routine meeting with Canadian border service agents Tuesday morning, Azizi Mirmahleh once again tried to plead her case, saying that if she is returned to Iran, her safety will be under threat.
Agents responded by detaining Azizi Mirmahleh in the immigration detention centre in Laval.
"She knows that she's in danger. They think because of that, my mother wouldn't show up at the airport," Bahrami told CBC.
Bahrami said she is very worried about her mother, who suffers from diabetes, high blood pressure, anxiety and back pain.
She said her mother has said in the past that if she were to be arrested, she would go on a hunger strike and refuse to take her medication.
"I am very worried for her health."
Mexican woman fighting deportation in Montreal fears for autistic son MEK linked to violence In an interview with CBC on Sunday, Azizi Mirmahleh explained that MEK, the group she was affiliated with, was seen as an opposition movement, and that it is popular among many Iranians.
She emphasized that the people she knew were peaceful.
Stéphanie Valois is the immigration lawyer handling Roghayeh Azizi Meermahleh's case. (CBC)
However, her lawyer, Stéphanie Valois, said the group's links to violence are the reason that her application for refugee status in Canada was refused.
"There was no evidence in this file that madame knew about terrorist activities, that she had any links with those activities," said Valois.
"The activities that she mentioned doing were connected to human rights, women's rights, rights of expression, and had nothing to do with terrorism in Iran."
Since arriving in Canada, Azizi Mirmahleh has been speaking out against the Iranian regime.
Videos of her protesting in Montreal have been circulating online — videos she believes Iranian agents will have seen.
'Iran is not a safe country' Kyle Matthews, head of the Montreal Institute for Genocide and Human Rights Studies at Concordia University, says Azizi Mirmahleh has reason to fear for her safety.
Kyle Matthews, head of the Montreal Institute for Genocide and Human Rights Studies at Concordia University, says Canada should stop deporting people to Iran because of that country's dismal human rights record. (CBC)
"I assume that if this person is deported back to Iran, there's a very good chance this person will end up in prison, could be tortured," Matthews said.
"We've seen that multiple times with various dissidents that have been returned. It's very likely that person will have their life and liberty put at great risk."
Matthews said that it's time Iran was added to the list of countries to which Canada will not deport refugee claimants, including Somalia and Syria.
"Iran is not a safe country. Iran has one of the most troubling human rights records of any country on the planet."
Montreal becomes 'sanctuary city' after unanimous vote 'I ask Canada: Don't do this' Now Bahrami is making a plea for help on her mother's behalf.
"I'm so stressed. I'm so shocked," she told CBC. "When we came here, we thought, we are safe here. And we asked for protection from Canada."
"The Iranian regime, they executed my father. They took away my father forever from me."
"I ask Canada: Don't do this," she went on.
"Don't separate my mother from me. Don't let the Iranian regime execute my mother. Don't do this. Please protect my mother."
Québec Solidaire MNA Amir Khadir, who was born in Iran, spoke about the case at the National Assembly.
MNA urges federal immigration minister to intervene Québec Solidaire MNA Amir Khadir spoke out about the case at the National Assembly Tuesday.
"If Canada makes the mistake of deporting [Azizi Mirmahleh] to Iran, Canada could have torture and blood on its hands," the Iranian-born medical doctor and MNA said.
Khadir told CBC in an interview Tuesday evening that Quebec's immigration minister, Kathleen Weil, and Montreal Mayor Denis Coderre are both "very concerned" about the case.
"I hope that at the Ministry of Immigration there will be a move in the upcoming hours," he said, adding that he believes Azizi Mirmahleh should be given a ministerial order that authorizes her to stay.
A spokeswoman for Weil, Gabrielle Tellier, told CBC in an email late Tuesday that the Quebec minister had been in touch with her federal counterpart throughout the day and has asked that the case be considered from a "humanitarian point of view" in order to stay Azizi Mirmahleh's deportation.
With files from Sarah Leavitt and Emily Brass
